title: No domestic abuse law will ever be enough if society continues to enables it
text:
No amount of laws or bills will make a difference while we live in a society that still accepts and enables domestic abuse (Picture: Jodi Hilton/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

Two years after it was meant to be passed, the Domestic Abuse Bill has finally received a second reading in Parliament.

It was refreshing to watch Parliament debate the issue and give it the emotion and intensity that it deserves.

However, despite advising on the bill myself, it is still nowhere near good enough – because no amount of laws or bills will make a difference while we live in a society that still accepts and enables domestic abuse.

A family member of mine, who had been emotionally, physically and financially abused for 30 years by someone threatening to kill her and leave her in the gutter, was told: ‘We all send texts, it doesn’t mean that he’s actually going to carry out the threats to kill you.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

I’ve consistently been asked ‘why didn’t she just leave?’. A male victim I spoke with recently had been told by police to sort it out ‘like a man’.

Is it any wonder so many people have this attitude when our politicians are just as bad? Last week Attorney General Geoffrey Cox remarked ‘when did you stop beating your wife?’ in a parliamentary discussion about prorogation.

It was apparently a ‘joke’ but the language our politicians use when talking about domestic abuse matters – it shapes and reflects what society thinks about this issue.

Listening to the debate on Wednesday, I was frustrated to hear the term ‘witness’ used to refer to children living in abuse. It shows that Parliament still doesn’t fully understand. Children don’t witness abuse – all children living in abusive homes are victims.

I want to make it very clear what domestic abuse is. It is power over somebody over time, using any kind of behaviour to maintain that power. That’s why victims are most at risk when they try to leave, because power is being taken away from the perpetrator, and they’ll do anything to get it back.

I keep reminding the government that the majority of abuse victims never even come into contact with the criminal justice system.

A major positive of the bill is that there will now be one amalgamated offence of domestic abuse because currently domestic abuse isn’t really against the law. It is treated as a series of one-off incidents, committed at different times, rather than a crime in its own right. Charges are often attached to other crimes like GBH, assault or harassment.

Advertisement

Advertisement

However, I keep reminding the government that the majority of abuse victims never even come into contact with the criminal justice system. Data from the Office of National Statistics for the year ending March 2018 showed that over four in five (83 per cent) of people who suffered partner abuse did not report it to the police.

I sat in Number 10 only last week speaking to ministers, pushing for them to have a trauma-informed response at the heart of policy. This means understanding the effects of trauma on people affected by abuse, focusing on what they have experienced rather than what is physically wrong with them.

I have also spoken about the long-term effects, which include mental illness such as PTSD, difficulty forming healthy relationships, re-victimisation, substance abuse and suicide, among others. As Labour MP Helen Hayes mentioned in the Commons, domestic abuse is the leading cause of homelessness.

The bill also includes proposals to ban the disgusting practice of perpetrators cross-examining their victim in family courts, which happens shockingly often and surely puts victims off from coming forward.

Yet it doesn’t confront the extremely flawed attitude of a ‘contact at all costs’ approach in the family courts, which puts children in danger. We wouldn’t leave a child with an abusive stranger so why would we leave a child with an abuser just because they are related?

In fact, it is trauma that happens to children in ‘caretaker’ relationships that can cause the most long term damage. This is something MPs need to recognise and address.

Advertisement

We seem to forget that children grow up to become adults. The trauma of domestic abuse still exists long after the abuse itself. The Adverse Childhood Experiences study revealed strong evidence that children who have been exposed to abuse in the home are more likely to attempt suicide as adults.

I wonder what would happen if we started to look at what’s going on in a child’s life when concerning behaviours are displayed?

For the government to really make a long-term difference for our next generation, they need to try and stop the abuse in the first place with early intervention and relationship education in schools, and offer proper emotional and financial support to victims. I’m sad to say this bill – even if passed – will not go nearly far enough.

On Wednesday, the Justice Secretary said he was speaking for ‘all victims’. We must make sure this is at the centre of our domestic abuse policy. It affects all cultures, all gender identities, all sexual orientations and all economic groups.

An all-inclusive, zero tolerance approach is the only way we are going to start preventing something that is so destructive.
